author: By Maya Phillips
title: Hate Superheroes? Maybe You Just Haven’t Met the Right One
description: Even if Avengers and Justice Leagues leave you cold, there’s probably some superpowered champion out there for you. Here’s a guide to the best nontraditional superhero stories available to stream.
content: We get it: Superheroes have overrun pop culture. Even though last summer’s blockbusters were thwarted by the coronavirus, Warner Bros. still brought an Amazon warrior to our TVs and laptops in December, and Disney+ has shrunk the Marvel Cinematic Universe to fit the smaller screens as well, with “WandaVision” and “The Falcon and the Winter Soldier.” If you thought the capesters’ reign was irksome back when Avengers were dominating multiplexes, you’re probably even more exasperated now. You’ve seen one guy in a mask and cape, you’ve seen them all, am I right?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taylor, Billie, Demi, Blackpink: The Pop Star Documentary Boom
description: A conversation about the influx of films made about (and by) current stars and its implications for the format.
content: It used to be that stars had to be reliably famous for a long time before documentary cameras chased them around. But everything is filmed now, anyhow, and pop stars are embracing this sort of serious treatment at earlier phases in their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The Falcon and the Winter Soldier’ Season 1, Episode 3: Friends in Low Places
description: This week’s episode is so packed with action that an entire prison riot and jailbreak gets dispatched in under five minutes of screen time.
content: Too often, TV series described by their creators as being “like a six-hour movie” have the kind of problems that actual six-hour movies might have. The pace can be unnecessarily slow, with characters spending a lot more time talking at length about what they’re going to do — or brooding over what they’ve already done — than taking action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Marder
title: Are Spring Sports Safe for Kids?
description: Youth sports are ramping up in many parts of the country. But without a vaccine for children, we still need to avoid spreading the coronavirus.
content: Leila Manuel is rarely without her soccer cleats. The 10 year old does drills at a field near her home on days with no practice and wears her club soccer jacket everywhere.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: The Matt Gaetz Investigation: What We Know
description: The Justice Department is said to be investigating the congressman’s encounters with women recruited online for sex and whether he had sex with a 17-year-old girl.
content: The Justice Department is investigating whether Representative Matt Gaetz, Republican of Florida and a close ally of former President Donald J. Trump, broke federal sex trafficking laws, focusing on his relationships with women recruited online for sex and whether he had sex with a 17-year-old girl, The New York Times reported this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Where Are the Least Fortunate Americans Supposed to Live?
description: Biden’s new $2 trillion-plus jobs plan recognizes that homes are part of the nation’s infrastructure.
content: On Wednesday, President Biden announced and outlined the next priority on his legislative agenda: a climate-centered infrastructure bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: How to Nudge People Into Getting Tested for the Coronavirus
description: Insights from behavioral economics and other fields suggest strategies that could increase participation in mass screening programs.
content: In October, Dr. Folasade May, an internist and public health researcher at the University of California, Los Angeles, began a new workplace routine. Once a week, she would make the three-minute walk from her office to a campus coronavirus testing site. After having her temperature checked and scanning a bar code on her phone, she would carefully swab the inside of her nose. Within a day or two, an email would arrive with her results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Signs of spring.
content: Want to get the At Home newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Pandemic Helps Stir Interest in Teaching Financial Literacy
description: Two dozen states are considering bills on the subject. Proponents say student debt and heightened interest in economic inequality are behind the efforts.
content: Two dozen state legislatures are considering bills on financial literacy education, an unusually high number, proponents say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China Puts Limits on Foreign Banks, Worrying Businesses
description: New rules, aimed at taming big money flows and possibly controlling the Chinese currency, could give domestic rivals a competitive edge and make international firms more dependent on local lenders.
content: SHANGHAI — To defend against accusations by Washington and others that it doesn’t play fair on trade, Beijing could point to the banks. Chinese leaders have been steadily lowering the barriers they had erected around the country’s vast financial system, giving Wall Street and European lenders a greater shot at winning business in the world’s second-largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert H. Frank
title: Why the Markets Need a Strong Government Hand
description: Individually rational actions often yield bad outcomes, an economist says. That incontestable fact is the central rationale for government involvement in economic life.
content: Milton Friedman, the Nobel laureate, is said to have joked that if the federal government were put in charge of the Sahara, in five years there would be a shortage of sand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Children’s Books Have Had the Biggest Impact on You?
description: In a recent Times article, an author wrote a heartfelt tribute to a beloved children’s author. What authors and books from childhood have made a mark on your life?
content: What books or authors stand out from childhood? Did any unlock the magic and joys of reading for you? Did any inspire, shape or guide the person you are today or hope to be?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Murphy Paul
title: Looking Forward to Your 170th Birthday
description: In “Ageless,” Andrew Steele explores the science of aging and the advances that might let humans prolong their lives by decades.
content: AGELESS The New Science of Getting Older Without Getting Old By Andrew Steele
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: Strong U.S. Job Growth in March Fuels Optimism on Recovery
description: The gain of 916,000 was the biggest since August, and unemployment fell to 6 percent. Barring a setback in fighting the virus, the outlook is bullish.
content: The American job market roared back to life in March — and with vaccinations accelerating, businesses reopening and federal aid flowing, the rebound should only get stronger from here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: After a music festival hoax, thousands flocked to a Brussels park, flouting rules.
description: An April Fool’s Day prank ended in clashes with the police.
content: BRUSSELS — In an April Fool’s Day joke that went wrong, a fake announcement of a music festival contributed to thousands gathering in a major park in Brussels on Thursday in defiance of Covid-19 restrictions. As the police confronted the crowd, several officers and participants were wounded, and four people were arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: In ‘Chad,’ Nasim Pedrad Embraces Her Inner Teen Boy
description: Pedrad, a “Saturday Night Live” alumna, plays the title character in her TBS comedy about an awkward 14-year-old trying to fit in.
content: For almost everyone, adolescence is a unique and personal caldron of anxiety. When Nasim Pedrad was growing up in Orange County, Calif., in the 1990s, she was simultaneously contending with a general, pubescent sense of mortification and the specific uncertainty of being a teenage immigrant who’d come to the United States from Iran at age 3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: David Cameron Comes Under the Spotlight for His Business Dealings
description: The former British prime minister has lobbied the government on behalf of an Anglo-Australian finance firm, Greensill Capital. While apparently legal, his activities set off a debate about lobbying by former leaders.
content: LONDON — Until last month, David Cameron was known for one big thing: calling the referendum in June 2016 that produced Britain’s shock vote to leave the European Union and triggered a political earthquake that toppled him as prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: A Virus Races Through the Horse World. No, Not That Virus.
description: In Europe, a deadly form of a common virus has killed nearly 20 horses and shut down competitions in 10 countries.
content: Shortly after arriving from abroad last month, Dr. Kent Allen’s new patient spiked a low fever. The doctor inserted a sterile swab into his patient’s nostril, a P.C.R. test to determine if this was yet another case of a potentially deadly virus sweeping the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Eileen Sullivan
title: Florida’s governor bans agencies and businesses from requiring ‘vaccine passports.’
description: The Biden administration has made clear that it will neither issue nor require so-called vaccine passports, but Republicans have seized on the issue as an example of government overreach.
content: Florida has banned state and local government agencies and businesses from requiring so-called vaccine passports, or documentation proving that someone has been vaccinated against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Is the Second Dose Bad? If I Feel OK, Is It Working? Can I Take Tylenol?
description: The most common questions about vaccination side effects, answered.
content: Every day nearly three million people in the United States are getting the Covid-19 vaccine. And every new jab prompts new questions about what to expect after vaccination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Margolick
title: These Sacred Jewish Books Were Abandoned. Could I Save Them?
description: Finding them in a trash bin saddened me. I couldn’t just put them back.
content: Several months ago, I was sifting through a pile of abandoned books in the most promising of places — a trash bin in a well-heeled and highly educated town, one of those communities where even the trash has class. Most of the offerings were depressing: cheap, pulpy paperbacks with raised letters on the cover; forgettable hardcovers; memoirs of second-tier celebrities; some of those classics you’ve always meant to read, but in editions you wouldn’t want to bring with you to bed.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Walter Isaacson
description: The April 2 episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Walter Isaacson. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Maggie Astor
title: The officer who secured the crime scene after George Floyd’s death is the first witness on Day 5.
description: Sgt. Jon Edwards, who has worked for the Minneapolis Police Department for more than 10 years, took the stand on Friday.
content: Witness testimony resumed Friday morning in the Derek Chauvin trial with Sgt. Jon Edwards of the Minneapolis Police Department taking the stand. Sergeant Edwards was sent to Cup Foods to secure the crime scene after police officers pinned George Floyd to the ground outside of the convenience store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Kenneth C. Kelly, Champion of Desegregation in California, Dies at 94
description: When Mr. Kelly, an engineer, wasn’t designing ways to communicate with spacecraft, he was opening doors for Black families to move into the San Fernando Valley.
content: Kenneth C. Kelly just wanted to buy a house near his office. An electrical engineer, he had moved to Los Angeles from New York in 1953; four years later, with a growing family, he dreamed of having a home in one of the city’s fast-growing suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: ‘Can’t Wait to Be Able to Hold Them’: Players’ Parents in an N.C.A.A. Bubble
description: The Stanford women’s basketball team has reached the Final Four after a long stretch as nomads, without familiar faces in the stands. Now in San Antonio, the Cardinal’s family and friends are making their presence known.
content: SAN ANTONIO — Michelle Bain-Brink took books and a container of macaroons to her daughter, Cameron, a freshman forward for Stanford, the morning after the team rallied against Louisville on Tuesday to advance to the Final Four in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament. Bain-Brink fully expected to leave the packages with a security guard who would send them to her daughter’s room in the team hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: How the Pandemic Has Made the Creative Class Feel Free
description: Hardcore business travelers have no intention of going back to the old ways. The workers who cater to their needs don’t have as many choices.
content: A few years ago, I served on my building’s co-op board with someone whose daily logistical demands made me realize I was just coasting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Queens Man Is Charged in 1976 Killing of Pregnant Teenager
description: Luis Sierra, 63, of Ozone Park, was arrested this week in the killing of Evelyn Colon, a Jersey City 15-year-old whose dismembered remains were found along a riverbank in Pennsylvania, the authorities said.
content: For more than 40 years, investigators were confounded by the circumstances surrounding the disappearance of a pregnant New Jersey teenager whose unidentified remains were found in several suitcases along a riverbank in Pennsylvania, along with a nearly full-term fetus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
title: America Has Long Favored Cars Over Trains and Buses. Can Biden Change That?
description: The president’s infrastructure plan tries to break from the past by shifting spending away from new roads and toward public transit. It won’t be easy.
content: If America is dominated by car culture and the call of the open road, there is a big reason for that: Over the past 65 years, the United States has spent nearly $10 trillion in public funds on highways and roads, and just a quarter of that on subways, buses and passenger rail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tess Thackara
title: Up on the Met Roof, an Artist Is Taking Big Bird to New Heights
description: Alex Da Corte, known for provocative, brightly colored installations, will showcase the beloved “Sesame Street’” character at the top of the Met this spring — but with a twist.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Among the characters that the artist Alex Da Corte has transformed himself into for his video work and installations are Eminem, Mister Rogers and the Wicked Witch of the West. In his Technicolor universe, American cultural icons share screen time with mascots from famous commercials, and even slasher-movie psychopaths are lovingly brought to life, with hours of prosthetics and tender, surgical-like observation. It’s a big-tent worldview that he shares, curiously, with “Sesame Street,” in which monsters, kids and grouches coexist — and in which he has discovered the subject for his latest artwork.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: uncanny
description: This word has appeared in 237 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Love Without Limitations
description: And: This couple’s first kiss was on their wedding day.
content: Not everyone wants to be with one partner forever, even if monogamy has had a long history of being the norm in romantic relationships. As more people begin to challenge old traditions, new forms of relationships are emerging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Dreamy Cowboys and a Ballet Bath
description: At Pacific Northwest Ballet, two online premieres: Donald Byrd’s has a Western theme and Alejandro Cerrudo’s undulates.
content: It takes only two oscillating notes to establish a world. The coyote howl that Ennio Morricone wrote for “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly” immediately conjures an idea of the American West: desert, tumbleweeds, gunslingers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Collage
description: What do you think this image is saying?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain and Christopher Flavelle
title: Test Flight for Sunlight-Blocking Research Is Canceled
description: The Swedish Space Corporation said it had canceled the flight — part of research to better understand the controversial idea of blocking the sun to fight climate change — after an outcry from environmentalists and others.
content: A test flight for researching ways to cool Earth by blocking sunlight will not take place as planned in Sweden this June, following objections from environmentalists, scientists and Indigenous groups there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: 5,000 Flee as Venezuela Launches Largest Military Campaign in Decades
description: The Venezuelan government has long tolerated armed groups trafficking drugs and contraband near its border with Colombia. Now it has lashed out at one of them, driving thousands of civilians into flight.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Venezuela is waging its most concerted military campaign in years, targeting what it says is a criminal group operating within its border near Colombia but also sending an estimated 5,000 of its own civilians fleeing into the neighboring country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Saudis keep control of the oil market despite a production increase.
description: Analysts said Saudi Arabia’s oil minister appeared to be calculating that by appeasing other oil producers, he can remain in control over the longer term.
content: For months, Saudi Arabia’s oil minister, Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman, arguably the most powerful individual in the oil business, has urged his fellow producers to keep a tight rein on output, fearing additional crude could flood the world’s markets and cause prices to drop. At the same time, some producers, notably Russia, have been chafing to open the spigot a bit more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Mets-Nationals Series Is Postponed by Virus Outbreak
description: Four Nationals players and a staff member have tested positive. The teams will try to play on Monday, against new opponents.
content: A day after pushing back the Mets’ season-opening game in Washington because of a coronavirus outbreak on the Nationals, Major League Baseball postponed the teams’ three-game weekend series on Friday. The league said it needed more time for follow-up testing and contact tracing after four Nationals players tested positive this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Wright
title: Takeaways from Day 5 of the Derek Chauvin trial.
description: Friday’s proceedings ended with critical testimony from the longest-serving officer in the Minneapolis Police Department, who testified that Mr. Chauvin’s actions were “totally unnecessary.”
content: Friday’s proceedings in the trial of Derek Chauvin ended with critical testimony from the longest-serving officer in the Minneapolis Police Department, who testified that Mr. Chauvin’s actions were “totally unnecessary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Bridgerton’ Star Regé-Jean Page Will Not Appear in Season 2
description: The breakout star of the Shonda Rhimes Netflix series has delivered his final zinger as the rakish Duke of Hastings.
content: Dearest readers, we have bad news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: She Never Dreamed of Acting. Now She’s an Oscar Nominee for ‘Minari.’
description: The veteran Korean star Yuh-Jung Youn has had a thriving career for five decades — all because of a choice she made when she failed her college entrance exam.
content: For her 60th birthday, the veteran Korean star Yuh-Jung Youn made herself a promise. She would collaborate only with those she trusts. Even if their ventures fell short, as long as she personally appreciated the people making them, the result wouldn’t much concern her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roslyn Sulcas
title: Review: And Now Four Dances, Completely Different
description: At Ballet National de Marseille, a varied night of dances by Lucinda Childs, Tânia Carvalho, Lasseindra Ninja and Oona Doherty.
content: MARSEILLE, France — The performance at the La Criée theater here, for a small number of invited guests and dance professionals, started just a few hours before President Emmanuel Macron announced the start of a third national lockdown. Although theaters have been closed since November, performers have been able to go on working and rehearsing; the filming of ballets, operas and plays is allowed, often with small invited audiences. Because going to work is allowed if a job can’t be done from home, these events don’t break any rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chuck Rocha
title: It’s Not Too Early to Start Courting Latino Voters
description: Democrats will need their votes to keep control of the Senate and House after the midterms.
content: Latino voters helped deliver the presidency to Joe Biden in 2020 by securing key victories in Arizona, Georgia, Nevada, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin. But Latino voters also moved an average of 9 percentage points from Democrats to Republicans in the 2020 elections compared with 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Aubry Kaplan
title: Let’s Stay Angry About Jan. 6
description: Rather than taking things in stride, I’m still saying, “How dare you?”
content: The events of Jan. 6 taste as bitter in my mouth as they did the day they took place. Nearly three months later, the simmering bad feeling isn’t boiling over anymore, but it’s still hot to the touch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Jeff Bezos Is Taunting Politicians. Will They Take the Bait?
description: A labor battle in Alabama is a referendum on Amazon’s strategy.
content: It’s hard to decide who is having a better troll moment on Twitter this week: Jeff Bezos or Lil Nas X.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: ‘A Really Good Moment’ for Canada in Washington
description: The Canadian ambassador discusses the sweeping changes in relations between Canada and the United States under the Biden administration.
content: While there’s no fast rule, the job of Canada’s ambassador to Washington often goes to a former politician or a high-profile Canadian who comes from outside of the ranks of career diplomats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong and Vivian Wang
title: A Chinese ‘Auntie’ Went on a Solo Road Trip. Now, She’s a Feminist Icon.
description: Tired of housework and an unhappy marriage, a 56-year-old woman has been on a six-month jaunt across China that has challenged deep-rooted gender norms.
content: She spends each night alone, curled up in a four-and-a-half by eight-foot rooftop tent, balanced on stilts above her car. She often eats her meals in parking lots. She has seen her daughter and grandchildren only once in the past six months, and her husband not at all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Hunter Biden’s Memoir, Translating Amanda Gorman and Learning to Love Cardboard: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: Take out your headphones, put down your phone and listen to New York Times journalism narrated by the reporters who wrote the story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Losing a Loved One Twice: First to Prison, Then to Covid’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the unique risks the coronavirus pandemic poses to correctional facilities and consider the disease’s effects on incarcerated people and their families.
content: Featured Article: “Losing a Loved One Twice: First to Prison, Then to Covid” by Jacey Fortin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: A Major Change to Life in New York’s Prisons and Jails
description: A  ban on long-term solitary confinement follows concerns about its effect on Black people and minors, and links to mental health problems.

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Russian Ex-Con of U.S. Penal System Meets and Taunts Imprisoned Navalny
description: The meeting between Maria Butina and Aleksei A. Navalny came after the Russian opposition leader declared a hunger strike to demand access to a doctor because of deteriorating health.
content: MOSCOW — Aleksei A. Navalny, the imprisoned Russian opposition leader, has been denied visits from his doctors and lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘Hemingway’ Is a Big Two-Hearted Reconsideration
description: Ken Burns’s latest documentary, premiering Monday on PBS, traces the complicated connections between the person, the persona and the stories
content: One of the more unsettling moments in “Hemingway,” the latest documentary from Ken Burns and Lynn Novick, finds Ernest Hemingway, big-game hunter, chronicler of violence and seeker of danger, doing one thing that terrified him: speaking on television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari and Vanessa Friedman
title: The Ghosts of Brooks Brothers
description: After the retailer filed for bankruptcy one couple was left with a warehouse full of abandoned mannequins and a price tag of nearly $250,000 to dispose of it.
content: ENFIELD, Conn. — The bones of Brooks Brothers stores are scattered across 100,000 square feet here in a warehouse near the Massachusetts border, mixed in with a sea of cardboard boxes and junk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Seven Infrastructure Problems in Urgent Need of Fixing
description: The Biden administration has pledged a $2 trillion investment in the nation’s infrastructure. With century-old water systems and schools vulnerable to earthquakes, there is no shortage of need.
content: Engineers say that when infrastructure works, most people do not even think about it. But they recognize it when they turn on a faucet and water does not come out, when they see levees eroding or when they inch through traffic, the driver’s awareness of the highway growing mile after creeping mile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: The C.E.O. of the self-driving car company Waymo will step down after more than 5 years.
description: The chief executive duties will be divided between two current company executives — Tekedra Mawakana and Dmitri Dolgov.
content: Waymo, the autonomous car unit of Google’s parent company, Alphabet, said John Krafcik is stepping down as chief executive after five and a half years at the helm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Stream These 5 Chilling New Horror Movies
description: Looking for some big scares, but overwhelmed by choices? We have picks for you.
content: Remember when you’d go to Old Country Buffet and you’d load up on lasagna, tater tots and brownies but it was nasty and then you were like, maybe I should have had the meatloaf, mashed potatoes and trifle? That’s what it’s like to be a horror movie fan now that streaming is a new normal. The choices are vast, the quality varies and the choosing is daunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: The U.K. reports more blood-clotting cases in people who received the AstraZeneca shot.
description: Some countries, including Germany, have restricted use over the issue, but British and European regulators say that incidences are rare and that the vaccine should continue to be given.
content: Britain reported 30 cases of extremely rare blood clots in people who had received the AstraZeneca-Oxford vaccine, the same sort of events that have prompted some European countries to restrict use of the shot in certain at-risk age groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson, Mahima Chablani and Desiree Ibekwe
title: The Daily: A Postcard From the Future
description: To envision a post-pandemic world, we called Betty Lou and Zita. Plus, we have a new show!
content: Hi everyone, happy Friday! Spring is happening (at least where we are), vaccine access is expanding and we’re feeling something like hope. So, inspired by our episode on one nursing home’s first day out of lockdown, we’re dedicating this newsletter to all the possibilities of a post-pandemic world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Turning to Russia, San Marino gave its vaccination campaign a jump start.
description: San Marino, a tiny, independent republic within northern Italy, is perhaps best known — to the extent it is known at all — as one of the smallest countries on earth.
content: San Marino, a tiny, independent republic within northern Italy, is perhaps best known — to the extent it is known at all — as one of the smallest countries on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: When reporters try to speak with Floyd’s family outside the courtroom, sheriff’s deputies step in.
description: The chief judge of Hennepin County has set strict rules prohibiting the Floyd family from speaking to the news media outside the courtroom.
content: On Wednesday afternoon, when Charles McMillian, a witness to the death of George Floyd, broke down while recounting what he saw last May, Judge Peter Cahill called a short recess to allow Mr. McMillian to compose himself.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The challenging latest chapter of the pandemic.
content: Experts warn that despite hope from Covid-19 vaccinations and a clearer path forward, it is much too soon to let down our guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mekado Murphy
title: Watch an Underwater Brawl in ‘Godzilla vs. Kong’
description: The director Adam Wingard narrates the sequence where the big ape and the giant lizard first spar in the film.
content: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Coca-Cola C.E.O.: Voting Rights Advocate?
description: A company with Southern roots and global reach tries to find its voice on an issue that disproportionately affects Black voters.
content: When James Quincey became chief executive of Coca-Cola in 2017, it’s fair to say he wasn’t focused on how to articulate the company’s position on the issue of voting rights. Instead, Mr. Quincey, who grew up in Birmingham, England, and has spent most of his career outside the United States, was consumed with the usual C.E.O. fare — expanding the business, keeping the share price up and not damaging the brand.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Inside the Biden Infrastructure Plan
description: A look at how the multitrillion-dollar package is a blueprint for sweeping social and economic change.
content: President Biden is pushing the boundaries of how most Americans think of infrastructure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: A Home Buyers’ Bonanza in Manhattan
description: Housing sales in New York City are finally picking up — along with deep discounts.
content: Anyone rooting for the recovery of New York City’s housing market has probably been heartened by the data trickling out of brokerages in the past few months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith
title: Pinterest Is Said to Be in Talks to Acquire the Photo App VSCO
description: The discussions between the digital pin board company and the app that inspired the “VSCO girls” trend are ongoing.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Pinterest has held talks to buy VSCO, a photography app that spawned a teenage social media craze, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jorge Ramos
title: The Perpetual Crisis at the Border — and What We Can Do About It
description: The U.S. immigration system doesn't reflect its own needs or those of its southern neighbors.
content: MIAMI — The U.S.-Mexico border is a “bleeding scar.” That is how Mexican author Carlos Fuentes described it in 1997. According to the Pew Research Center, 1.2 million immigrants, authorized and unauthorized, entered the United States that year. Back then, just like now, there was talk of an overwhelming crisis at the border.

author: By Kate Branch
title: When Ancient Rome Meets Minimalism
description: Brioni’s Norbert Stumpfl has approached his family’s home with characteristic patience and attention to detail.
content: One understandable reaction to spending more time at home is to stockpile objects meant to provide comfort. Probably even dedicated minimalists have pondered, as of late, what another throw or accent pillow might do for their space and mental state. But, while he is certainly not averse to an elegant sort of ease, Norbert Stumpfl, the executive design director of the Italian men’s wear label Brioni, has always put a great deal of time and care into his aesthetic choices, with results that are so precise as to feel inevitable. This is apparent from his clothing collections, consisting of expertly tailored, handmade suits and separates in luxurious wools and silks — and from the three-story, 3,200-square-foot townhouse in central Rome where the Austria-born designer, 44, lives with his wife, Daphne Karras, a ceramist, and their two daughters.

content: Tesla said on Friday that it more than doubled the number of cars it delivered in the first quarter, bouncing back after the pandemic slowed sales in the same period a year ago.

title: The Pandemic Hit the Working Class Hard. The Colleges That Serve Them Are Hurting, Too.
description: The community colleges largely serving low-income, Black and Latino students are reeling, and experts worry that inequality in education will increase.
content: The coronavirus pandemic has been uniquely hard on America’s working class, causing higher unemployment among people without college degrees and eliminating low-wage jobs by the millions. Now, the education system created to help those very workers also is in jeopardy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: I Used to Think the Remedy for Bad Speech Was More Speech. Not Anymore.
description: How kids, lawsuits and legislation can save democracy.
content: I used to believe that the remedy for bad speech is more speech. Now that seems archaic. Just as the founders never envisioned how the right of a well-regulated militia to own slow-loading muskets could apply to mass murderers with bullet-spewing military-style semiautomatic rifles, they could not have foreseen speech so twisted to malevolent intent as it is now.

content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This is an excellent example of a themeless crossword puzzle, and it’s a half debut, to boot. By “half debut,” I mean that this collaboration was between Kyra Wilson — the debutante, sorry, I meant debutee — and Sophia Maymudes, who has had four puzzles in The Times.

title: Baseball’s back, and it’s ‘good to hear humans in the stands.’
description: They opened the gates on Thursday, six months after the end of a brief and surreal regular season played before cardboard cutouts and empty stands. Opening day for 2021 brought none of the usual standing-room-only crowds; with limited capacities, the games looked more like sleepy gatherings in mid-April. But the buzz was authentic, and there’s nothing like the real thing.

content: On their second date, Dr. Anais Ovalle and Emily Black got lost hiking at the Moose Hill Wildlife Sanctuary in Sharon, Mass. Snow fell and then it got dark. Even though they lost cellphone service for a while and eventually had to call an Uber to get to their cars, both kept their cool.

content: HOW MUCH OF THESE HILLS IS GOLD, by C Pam Zhang. (Riverhead, 336 pp., $16.) Our reviewer, Martha Southgate, compared this “arresting” debut novel, about the long journey of two Chinese-American siblings to bury their failed gold-rush-prospector father in the sweepingly beautiful and barren American West, to, yes, Faulkner’s “As I Lay Dying” and Steinbeck’s “The Grapes of Wrath.”

title: Sorry, Sometimes You Do Have to Be Uncomfortable

title: Two Brothers Posed for a Portrait. One Lived to See It in the Met.
description: Alice Neel painted two neighborhood boys in her studio in the 1960s. Fifty years later, the mystery of what happened to the picture has been solved.
content: When Jeff Neal was 8 or 9 years old, an older friend would take him and his brother Toby on trips around the city. They’d go to the Empire State Building or the parks, and one day they went to a large apartment on the Upper West Side that was filled with paintings.

content: Washington’s robust spending in response to the coronavirus crisis is helping to pull the United States out of its sharpest economic slump in decades, funneling trillions of dollars to Americans’ checking accounts and to businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: He’s a Murderer, a Stalker, a Creep — and an Entertaining Narrator
description: Joe Goldberg, the psychopath we met in Caroline Kepnes’s first novel, “You,” is back for a third time in “You Love Me,” and he’s got a new obsession.
content: Caroline Kepnes must be some kind of storytelling sorcerer. How else can Joe Goldberg — stalker, creep, multiple murderer, blamer of everyone else but himself, a “long overdue book, the one you never thought was coming” — be such an entertaining narrator? Even Tom Ripley, Patricia Highsmith’s famously amoral character (a clear inspiration for Kepnes), could be enjoyed at a third-person remove, unlike the in-your-face immediacy of Joe’s blinkered perspective.

title: After Claims of Sexual Abuse, Oxfam Suspends 2 Workers in Africa
description: The accusations in the Democratic Republic of Congo came three years after the British charity’s government assistance was suspended over sexual exploitation in Haiti.
content: Oxfam has suspended two staff members over accusations of sexual misconduct in the Democratic Republic of Congo in recent years, the British charity said on Friday, months after commissioning a broader investigation into abuse claims in the central African nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Constance Demby, New Age Composer, Is Dead at 81
description: Ms. Demby wrote ethereal, otherworldly music and played much of it on instruments of her own making, including one she called the Space Bass.
content: Constance Demby, whose ethereal music, some of it played on instruments she designed, was much admired by New Age adherents, spiritual seekers and fans of electronica, died on March 19 in Pasadena, Calif. She was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello and Patricia Mazzei
title: Trump’s Latino Support Was More Widespread Than Thought, Report Finds
description: While Latinos played a major role in Democratic victories last year, Donald Trump’s outreach to them proved successful in states around the country, not just in certain geographic areas.
content: Even as Latino voters played a meaningful role in tipping the Senate and the presidency to the Democrats last year, former President Donald J. Trump succeeded in peeling away significant amounts of Latino support, and not just in conservative-leaning geographic areas, according to a post-mortem analysis of the election that was released on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: The Unmitigated Chaos of America’s Attempt at Color-Coded Covid Guidance
description: Many states use color-coded tiers to signal coronavirus restrictions. Why are they all wildly different?
content: In California, the color of suffering is the juicy purple of seedless grapes. In Alabama and Alaska, it’s blood-colored. Blue signifies safety in many states, unless the blue is navy and you’re in Utah, in which case it communicates total catastrophe — the worst conditions possible. In New Mexico, nothing is better than green except for a color the governor’s office used to call “green-plus,” before it was changed to turquoise.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Officials identified the suspect as Noah R. Green, 25. He had posted on Facebook about Mr. Farrakhan and the “end times.”

title: Myanmar’s Bloodshed Reveals a World That Has Changed, and Hasn’t

content: Myanmar’s rulers this week crossed a threshold few governments breach anymore: They have killed, by most estimates, more than 500 unarmed citizens of their own country.

content: SAN MARINO — On the ground floor of the only hospital in San Marino, a tiny, independent republic perched high above the surrounding Italian countryside, nurses prepared Covid-19 vaccine doses from glass vials labeled in Cyrillic script, flicked needles and sought to put nervous residents at ease.

content: A year into the pandemic, it’s easy to find yourself reminiscing about the past: bustling restaurants, sweaty spin classes, grocery shopping unburdened by face masks and cascades of adrenaline. content: After a year of disproportionate loss from the pandemic and the continuous threat of police violence, on top of centuries of discrimination and disenfranchisement, what does healing look like for Black Americans? Thanks to the Trump White House and Mitch McConnell’s Senate, there is now a 6-to-3 conservative majority on the Supreme Court, vetted by conservative legal activists and committed to principles of constitutional interpretation that seem to require sweeping Roe v. Wade away, or at least modifying it into obsolescence.

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Yes, There Are Nice Landlords in New York

content: In the early 1970s, Margo Margolis was part of a movement to transform Manhattan’s SoHo from an industrial wasteland to an affordable haven for artists. A young painter, she rented a cheap loft there and converted it into a studio and living space. When her landlord went bankrupt, she and her fellow artist tenants pooled money and bought their building to run as a co-op. Around them, galleries and scrappy businesses began springing up. One of her favorites was Pearl River Mart.

The Australian-born founder of Chandelier Creative, a New York-based creative agency known for its work with major fashion and commercial retail brands, was “pitching, pitching, pitching,” he says, constantly courting new business and traveling between offices in New York, Los Angeles and Paris. He was up early for flights, out late with clients and routinely jittery from coffee and wine. One year, he was JetBlue’s number one flier. “And I was so proud of it,” he says. “But I’m ashamed of it now — because I was living outside of my body.”
